pullRequest.title: Add progress counts for more job types

beforeCommit.message: Add progress counts for more job types

afterCommit.message: Add progress counts for more job types

nodes.bodyText: Is there any reason to restrict which jobs we allow counts on? Seems like anything that has num set and greater than zero should be displayed. Also, I think its okay to display num even if total isn't set, just display without the second half

commit.message:
* Set totalClicks earlier
* Add TransferBinariesToStorageJob counts

beforeCommit.message:

afterCommit.message:
* Set totalClicks earlier

nodes.bodyText: Hmm, with this approach the total count will shrink if you resume the job. It may be easiest to switch the count to be the number of objects being processed rather than the number of files. In that case you should be able to precompute the total (I believe counting the total number of subjects in the model will get you this), and the counts will be in line with most of the other jobs

This section looks good. While testing it, I was finding with so many additional progress numbers showing it was getting a bit hard to differentiate between all the numbers next to each other. Adding some text to split up the progress from the time spent helps a little. Changing the following line: https://github.com/UNC-Libraries/Carolina-Digital-Repository/blob/fcrepo4/static/templates/admin/statusMonitor/depositMonitorJobDetails.html#L30 to put "in" between progress and time:
  • <%= job.shortName %> <%= job.status %> <%= job.completion %> <% if (job.time) { %> in <%= job.time %> <% } %>

commit.message: Use subject counts to get total count

nodes.bodyText: I don't think the click counts will line up with the total anymore, since clicks are still counting number of files while the total is the number of resources. I believe you'll need to move the addClicks call into transferBinaries since that iterates over each resource in the model.

commit.message: Move counting into the TransferBinaries method

nodes.bodyText: I think you might have to reset the click count between runs, otherwise the count is going to be higher than the total after a resume. Not sure if trying to skip addClick during a resume would be practical, but maybe its possible?

commit.message: Reset click count if a job is resumed
